sub_topic: The measurement of the top quark mass
message_1: What is the top quark mass and how is it measured in particle physics experiments?
message_2:
The top quark is the heaviest of all known elementary particles and is a member of the third-generation quark family. Its mass is approximately 173.1 GeV/c² (giga-electron volts divided by the speed of light squared), which is about 185 times heavier than a proton.

The top quark mass is measured in particle physics experiments using high-energy particle colliders, such as the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN and the Tevatron at Fermilab. These colliders accelerate protons or other particles to extremely high speeds and smash them together, creating a shower of new particles, including top quarks.

Top quarks are highly unstable and decay almost immediately into other particles. They are typically produced in pairs, with one top quark and one anti-top quark. The decay products of the top quark can include a bottom quark and a W boson, which can further decay into other particles such as leptons and quarks. By analyzing the decay products and their kinematic properties, physicists can reconstruct the mass of the top quark.

There are several methods used to measure the top quark mass, including:

1. Template method: This method involves comparing the distribution of a kinematic variable (such as the invariant mass of the decay products) in the experimental data to simulated distributions for different top quark masses. The mass that provides the best match to the data is considered the measured top quark mass.

2. Matrix element method: This method uses the probabilities of different decay processes, calculated from the fundamental theory of particle physics (quantum chromodynamics), to determine the most likely top quark mass that would produce the observed decay products.

3. Ideogram method: This method combines elements of the template and matrix element methods, using both the kinematic distributions and the matrix elements to determine the most likely top quark mass.

These methods, along with others, are used in combination to obtain the most precise measurement of the top quark mass. The current world-average value for the top quark mass, as of 2021, is approximately 173.1 ± 0.9 GeV/c².
